data.text: **Give a Gift/Get a Gift**

**GIVE A GIFT:** A gift subscription to The Bridge World not only provides 12 exciting monthly reminders of your thoughtfulness, it is also a delicate compliment, a token of respect, a sign that the recipient has arrived as a serious bridge player or fan. It is also an ideal way to improve your partner's game. We will send gift cards that you can sign and present personally at the appropriate time.
**GET A GIFT FOR YOURSELF:** For each gift subscription you order, choose a bonus for yourself from these books of Bridge World reprints:

BRIDGE WITH ALGY by Alfred Sheinwold, [ALGY] commemorates the achievements of a giant, republishing of the first great bridge-story series.

THE USEFUL SPACE PRINCIPLE and TRANSFER ADVANCES OF OVER-CALLS by Jeff Rubens [USP] reviews the theory behind kickback, grand-slam nonforce, Rubensohl, and more; plus MSC excerpts on transfer advances.

BRIDGE WITH JACKIE, Book 1, by A. Moyse, Jr. [BWJ1]

BRIDGE WITH JACKIE, Book 2, by A. Moyse, Jr. [BWJ2]
are collections of battle-of-the-sexes stories from our favorite curmudgeon.

THE BEST OF ROBERT GRAY, Book 1 [RG1]

THE BEST OF ROBERT GRAY, Book 1 [RG2]
reprint humorous and technically brilliant articles by a star puzzler-analyst.

THE BEST OF FRANK VINE [FV] presents some favorite entertaining articles.

BRIDGE IN MUTTROPOLIS, Book 1, by Jeff Rubens [MUT1] reprints seven favorites (1968-1981) about bridge in the big city.

BRIDGE IN MUTTROPOLIS, Book 2: The Bet, by Jeff Rubens [MUT2] reprints the entire fantasy-satire (1977-1978), our most popular series.

BRIDGE IN WONDERLAND by Jeff Rubens, [WON] includes the entire series of widely acclaimed "Alice" articles, and more, from the sixties.

APPEALS COMMITTEE 1 [AC1]

APPEALS COMMITTEE 2 [AC2]
provide a pleasant way to learn the rules, know your rights, judge well.

BRIDGE WORLD: BEST OF THE EARLY 60's [BOE] with an all-star cast.

RATE YOUR OWN GAME [RY] presents 30 articles from the early days.

BRIDGE MOVIES AND POST-MORTEMS [MOV] contains problems (the mov-ies) and delightful rehashes from major tournaments.

CHALLENGE THE CHAMPS Book 3 (1968-1969) [CTC3]

CHALLENGE THE CHAMPS Book 4 (1969) [CTC4]

CHALLENGE THE CHAMPS Book 5 (1970) [CTC5]

CHALLENGE THE CHAMPS Book 6 (1970-1971) [CTC6]

CHALLENGE THE CHAMPS Book 7 (1971) [CTC7]

You plan to win the (say, red-suit) return, ruff a club, cross to hand with a trump, ruff a second club, return to the other red suit, draw trumps and claim. Only a red-suit void or a horrific club split will doom this plan. Note that you would be slightly more exposed to a ruff or an overruff if you trumpped any clubs before losing a spade trick.
**Solution B**
Suppose you duck the first trick. This would rectify the count for a criss-cross squeeze against East. You would win the return and run winners, to reach:

East can keep only three cards. If he started with the sole guard in diamonds and clubs (as in the diagram), he will have been squeezed. You guess the suit he has unguarded, then cash the ace of that suit to take the rest of the tricks.

However, that line of play is overly optimistic. West cannot be expected to behave like a trained seal. He can tell, just as well as you, that East's hand looks something like 1=0=6=6. Given the opportunity, a competent West will shift to a club at trick two; bye bye squeeze!

A better try is to win with the heart ace and run spades, to reach:

Assuming East has the sole minor-suit guards, he will have been squeezed. As in the standard criss-cross squeeze, described above, you must guess his shape. If East has reduced to two or fewer diamonds, you play on diamonds to make an overtrick. Otherwise, East has at most two clubs; you continue with club ace, diamond king, club, to set up the dummy.

**OUR INTERNET ADDRESS**

You can enjoy services and entertainment at our World Wide Web site: www.bridgeworld.com. Please tell your friends that there is plentiful material there for beginners as well as for players at all other skill levels.

**The View from Vu-Graph**

by Kit Woolsey, Kensington, CA

As the coach of the USA-1 team in the 1997 Bermuda Bowl, played during October in Tunisia, I had many opportunities to watch matches on the Vu-Graph. One nice feature of this perspective is that you get the advantages of being a spectator, yet can openly discuss the deal as it is being played, gaining additional insights from the observations of others. Of course, anyone who can see all four hands must take great care not to let knowledge of the layout affect his analysis or evaluation of the players' actions.

In Tunisia, the smart money made three teams roughly equal co-favorites to win the Bowl: France and the two United States entries. This time, the smart money was smart indeed. All three teams reached the semifinals, and France defeated USA-2 narrowly in the final. This report follows the 20-board-match between France and USA-1 in the qualifying round-robin, one of the most interesting I have ever seen, from the position of a Vu-Graph observer. I emphasize my thoughts as I was watching and discussing the match. To preserve the flavor of an actual Vu-Graph show, we override the usual Bridge World procedure of making South the declarer when possible and instead leave the players in their fixed geographical positions throughout the article: For the U. S., Michael Rosenberg was West and Mahmood Zia East; for France, Paul Chemla was South and Michel Perron North.

these days) to enlighten us about Al Sobel. Another famous director, Harry Goldwater, had a rule to accept all leads out of turn because any player who isn't smart enough to know whose lead it is certainly isn't smart enough to make the best opening lead. Here, however, you surely don't want to accept a heart lead from RHO—you might as well tear up your queen.

**Ron Gerard**: "c. Who needs this agita? (a) and (b) are clearly wrong and (c) is pointless; (d) runs the risk of drawing a club lead. I expect something like,

♠ A K Q 10 x x x ♥ K x ♦ x x ♣ A x.

But please don't force me to waste mental energy on this stuff."

Ouch!

Amidst all the grumpiness, there was a panelist who thought there might be some subterfuge afoot.

**Mahmood Zia**: "d. East is the Rueful Rabbit holding ace-queen-jack-ten-low of clubs and finding the only lead out of turn to beat this!"

**Bobby Wolff**: "c. A great problem with a real guess by us. I'm hoping for ace-low, not king-low, in hearts from partner. The two-heart bidder may have a solid club suit, with dummy having solid spades."

*Solid* clubs aren't likely, but we still see no reason to give the defense a chance to lead that suit. We *know* that we have at least one, and probably two, heart stoppers, and positionally we think a heart lead from West is fine. A majority agree:

**Carl Hudecek**: "c. I don't mind a heart lead knowing RHO has only low one(s). I prefer to have *West* lead the heart."

**Chip Martel**: "c. It's hard to see how it can be better to have East lead hearts rather

than West, so a and b are out. Also, why have the heart eight as a penalty card?"

**Kit Woolsey**: "c. This puts me even with the field, except when West has a surprise club lead—then I gain. Partner should have something in hearts to bid three notrump (he could have bid three hearts otherwise), so I can't mind the heart lead too much."

**Marshall Miles** (with **Mark Bartusek** and **Henry Bethe** similarly): "c. I suspect that a club lead would be better for the defenders, so I don't want to bar a heart lead."

**John Carruthers**: "c. Interesting twist. Partner should have a heart stopper, as I did not promise one. Still, I'll look pretty foolish if a heart is the only lead to beat it. It won't be for the first, or the last, time. (And just because I told you guys I'm pretty thick-skinned does not give you free rein to flay me!)"

We'll save our flayings for your comedic answers. Speaking of comedy,

**Steve Weinstein**: "c. Seems like partner wants a heart lead, I think I want a heart lead, East wants a heart lead—so let's make West lead a heart."

Any way you say it, (c) makes sense. But not to:

**Mary & Max Hardy**: "d. Why should we want a heart lead?"

Because we have queen-third.

**Phillip Alder**: "d. Despite Goldwater's rule, I see this as a toss-up between c and d. I lean slightly toward the latter. I might even get a diamond lead. And, as East might have one entry, I would prefer that to be the first heart attack."

**John Lowenthal**: "d. Normally, I choose the 'penalty card' option when the situation is not clear, but here I think there is a real chance that West will try a diamond if I bar the heart lead."

cessful. After some thought Zia did shift, but to a spade—he was playing his partner for ace-fourth of spades. The swing to France was small, as East-West went down one in two spades in the other room.

Are there bridge problems that are peculiar to Vu-Graph watching? Absolutely. If you want to test yourself, while you are checking out the routine French contract of three clubs, try to figure out how South might have made eleven tricks at hearts.

Three clubs was clearly cold, so we had time to try to figure out the unlikely looking result from the closed room—two hearts, making five! This seems impossible, as declarer has three trump losers in addition to other problems. However, observe what can happen on a spade lead. Declarer wins the finesse, and cashes all his top tricks, ruffing two spades in the closed hand and a diamond in dummy. At trick ten, declarer leads another diamond. West, who has followed suit throughout, ruffs, and dummy overruffs with the ten. When a club is led from dummy, West can do

no better than overruff with the nine and then lead away from his ace of hearts. Magic! My audience-mate, Joanna Stansby, pointed out that West could have avoided the endplay and gained a trick through the odd play of ruffing the last diamond with his ace of hearts.

Think along with Zia on Board 4. With both sides vulnerable, there are two passes to you. What call would you make with,

♠ 8 3  ♥ J 9 8 7 5  ♦ A Q J 4 2  ♣ J?

Zia earned a nice swing by opening a weak two diamonds. This directed what would have been the killing lead against three notrump, a contract bid and made in Closed Room after a third-position one-heart opening. The French tried five clubs, defeated one trick.

After both sides bid aggressively to a thin game that made, France picked up a big swing from the good and bad luck attached to different leads against a game contract.

Board 7 was not too interesting in the match—both teams went down after opening a strong notrump when they could have succeeded in a four-four spade fit—, but it was a lively one in our discussion group. Joanna and I constantly debate the merits weak notrump vs. strong notrump. She clearly won this round. The deal also showed the different ways that random events can influence the results. Zia and Rosenberg use weak notrumps nonvulnerable, strong notrumps vulnerable. Unfortunately for the U. S., they were vulnerable here.

One of the problems with opening a

bids three of a minor I will know what to do."

Does everyone know if partner's three-of-a-major rebid is forcing over two notrump? Some play that three-of-a-major shows a weak five-five (three-heart bid) or a weak six-four (three-spade bid). Holding a game force, opener transfers with an artificial three clubs and then bids three-of-a-major, forcing.

JEFF RUBENS (and PHILLIP ALDER similarly): "Two notrump. I reject two spades. Among the other choices, all seriously flawed, two notrump has the best recovery chances should I be naming the wrong strain."

MICHAEL ROSENBERG (and JOHN CARRUTHERS similarly): "Two notrump. If partner bids three of a major, raise to four. If partner bids three clubs, bid three notrump. If partner bids three diamonds, bid five clubs (super-cue). Finally, if partner bids three notrump (presumably 5=4=2=2), bid four diamonds, offering a choice between the majors and showing diamond values (obviously with three low clubs, else I would pass three notrump)."

And now, the shudders.

HENRY BETHE: "Two spades. If partner can bid again, I can show the hearts and get to game or even, over three diamonds, reach slam. The problem with three hearts is that it is too committal as to strain, and I'm not at all sure."

Reaching slam after that start would be a first.

BILLY EISENBERG: "Two spades. The old mark-time bid."

But you'd mark the same time if the king-queen of hearts were the three-deuce.

AL ROTH: "Two spades. I must miss a game once in a while, but I don't mind missing a non-vul. game. However, partner may bid again—and if so, I will get to game."

Sounds as if he forgot the usual, "if I just get by this round."

ERIC RODWELL: "Two spades. Very close between two spades and two notrump. Three notrump is good opposite, ♠ K Q 10 x x ♥ A J x x ♦ x ♣ K J x, but not opposite, ♠ A K x x x ♥ A J x x ♦ x x ♣ Q x, or less. Two spades gives partner another chance, and we are not vulnerable."

Now that's interesting. Rodwell considers trying for game opposite one of his openings, while Roth, Mr. Strong One-Bid himself, is happy to bid only two spades.

CHIP MARTEL: "Two spades. While you have a lot of high cards, you aren't likely to make a game. Give partner, ♠ A K x x x ♥ A J x x ♦ J x ♣ K x, and no game is very good."

MARK BARTUSEK: "Two spades. I'll be conservative, as only a non-vul. game is at stake. I don't particularly like three hearts or three spades, but two notrump is worth considering because partner might pattern out on the way to game."

He can pattern out over two spades just as easily.

MARSHALL MILES: "Two spades. Partner's most likely distribution is 5=4=1=3, in which case my hand isn't worth much. But I've got to keep the bidding open, just in case partner has a decent hand."

Only one panelist didn't want to keep the bidding open.

JOHN LOWENTHAL: "Pass. Take a plus, let them try to guess out this nightmare at the other table."

After a trump lead, declarer, Chemla, drew another round of trumps and tried ace and king of clubs, which seems like a reasonable line. I was wondering if it might not be better immediately to play the ace and king of hearts, continuing with a heart ruff high if an honor fell on the second round. If both heart honors come down, the contract will then be cold regardless of the black-suit splits. However, this approach loses on some four-one club splits when the actual line of play would have succeeded, such as when a defender holds two trumps and one club. Perhaps the answer depends on how often it will occur to the defenders to dump a heart honor on the second round of hearts and thus deflect declarer to a losing line of play. Another possible improvement for South is to cash a high club at trick two. Then, if the club queen drops, heart ace, heart ruff high, diamond ace, heart ruff high, spade nine to dummy, draw trumps, club jack, diamond king, club king. On the lie of the cards, all plays were booked for success, so the result was duplicated.

He has ushered us into F3 by announcing that if you voted "Yes" to F2, then you should continue on the same party line and pass on F3. We agree. To bid five-over-five you should have extreme shape. Perhaps a weak hand with a seven-card suit, or maybe a diamond void. We can't know for sure how many trumps there are (Carruthers' math seems to point to about 20), and the Law does not give us a perfect conclusion. If partner is 4=4=0=5, then bidding surely will be right, but if he has that 3=3=2=5 strong hand, we're best off passing. Since it's a guess, why not follow the well-known bridge adages?

KIT WOOLSEY (and ERIC RODWELL similarly): "F3. Pass. When in doubt, let the opponents play at the five level. We have no assurance of a good fit, and, when we have a good fit, no guarantee that we will find it."

Or maybe even real-life clichés?

SAMI KEHELA: "F3. Pass. Half a loaf is better than no bread."

How about this old catchphrase:

CHIP MARTEL: "F3. Pass. I would pass and 'stay fixed.' "

We have the optimistic passers . . .

CARL HUDECEK: "F3. I pass and collect my 800-plus."

. . . the practical ones . . .

JOHN CARRUTHERS: "F3. Pass. If we can make anything, we'll get 300 to 500; if we can't, any plus will be good. And my ace says they can't make."

. . . and the mathematical ones . . .

**Fifty Years Ago**

Many of the top players of fifty years ago had a great flair for card play. Often, they seemed to conjure up a brilliant line of play or defense with little or no calculation, as though through intuition or inspiration. No one exemplified the instinctive player more, in quality or quantity of superior plays, than Harry Fishbein. This Fishbein exploit, from the team-of-four event at the 1947 Winter Nationals, was reported in the Jaunary, 1948, issue of *The Bridge World*.
A popular start to the auction was:

Four hearts was a popular contract around the room. The defense attacked spades, and most Souths discarded diamonds on the second and third rounds of the suit, keeping control—except that hearts broke five-one so the contract was defeated.

Fishbein was the only South to make four hearts. He ruffed the second spade, cashed two clubs, and crossruffed for ten tricks. Notice that discarding at tricks two and three relies on better than five-one breaks in two suits, hearts and clubs, while the winning line requires only one decent break, in clubs. Still, we doubt that Fishy calculated the exact odds.

appropriate entries; in the ACBL's ranking system, almost every tournament player was a "Master" of some sort or other.

Variations notwithstanding, there are basically two kinds of tournament reports. One aims mainly at presenting interesting or instructive deals, the other at reporting and accounting for the results. Although he was not the sole inventor of any techniques, Edgar brought new dimensions to both varieties. To the "good deals" type, he added the common-theme approach nowadays typically applied in non-reportorial articles. For an illustration, let's look at some snatches from the thematic report of his atypical triumph in the Individual, from the March, 1957, issue of The Bridge World.

**Life Masters Individual**

by Edgar Kaplan

While I enthusiastically approve of the result of this year's Masters Individual, I can't say that I had a very good time playing in it. And I usually do. This is a nerve-shattering tournament if you're in a good position to win. I could never relax and really enjoy the mad scramble. [Editor's note (by Moyse): It has, perhaps, been subtly indicated that Mr. Kaplan was the winner of this year's Masters Individual, with its record-breaking field of 136, but we like to make everything pellucidly clear: He was.]

There are three factors in the winning of this event: you must play reasonably well; you need a lot of fortitude; and you must be enormously lucky. Luck is the theme of this article, as it should be in one about the Individual.

There are many kinds of good luck in bridge, and I had all of them. In this first hand I was lucky enough to have my partner make an excellent play. (In this event, in which even the best players produce their worst bridge, this is the very height of luck.)

I was South, playing with Geoffrion, of Montreal. . . .

. . . a well-deserved top for my partner, a lucky top for me.

Another Canadian, Eric Murray, of Toronto, also earned an excellent score for me with accurate play, but he was my opponent. . . .

. . . This last hand was the luckiest of all. It came up in the final session, and the tournament hinged on the outcome.

In contrast, Edgar assumed that the reader began with an appropriate respect for the world's top players and moved on from there. If he thought someone had messed up he said so, and explained why. This novel approach brought tournament descriptions up from the old boy network to the level of at least semi-responsible reporting; once Edgar had done it, others did also. The upheaval in bridge journalism began less than two years after "New Science" had begun to revolutionize table behavior. It was less dramatic, but its effects were equally long lasting.

In his first big-time tournament report, arguably the best ever, Edgar used a box-score approach, daring to record his view of the exact effectiveness of each of the participants in the match between Italy and the United States that decided the 1958 Bermuda Bowl. Every educated person should be familiar with the entire document, which extended over five issues of The Bridge World (beginning in September, 1958), but here you'll have to settle for an abridgement that tries to preserve the flavor of the original. (The imps in this match are "old imps," roughly twice the size of current imps; so, 5 old imps is more or less 10 current imps, etc.)

**The 1958 World Championship**

by Edgar Kaplan

I have just finished an exhaustive analysis of all 164 hands of the 1958 World Championship match, United States vs. Italy, at Lake Como.

Mainly, my objective has been to assign "charges." How many international match-points did each player cost his team? Who were most effective and least effective for each side?

Before presenting conclusions, let me outline my method of charging. Take, for example, Deal 100 (right col):

Silodor and Rapée bid the East-West cards to the normal unbeatable contract of four spades. However, at the other table the bidding went:

ledger, I put those five IMP in a special column for adverse swings caused, not by error, but by bad luck or by hands especially suited to the opponents' bidding style. I kept two of these "Act of God" columns, one for each team, and with all the results in, comparison would show if one team was substantially luckier than the other.

The final tabulation shows three types of notations in each player's column: charges for errors, credits for brilliance, and black marks for uncharged errors. The net figure is the player's total IMP charges, less IMP credits, plus (for I am a purist) a one-point charge for each black mark. This net figure, divided by the number of boards played, gives a fraction—actually, the number of IMP lost per board played—which, in my opinion, is a reliable index of general effectiveness.

Since this article will take the form of analysis of each player's performance, it will, inevitably, deal more with personalities than is the custom in bridge reports. I make no apology for this. My team has not done well enough to give us a chance to play for the U.S. next year; I am not in a glass house, and so I can afford to throw stones. But it is only fair to emphasize the obvious: opportunities for brilliance are few; for error, countless. In addition to the few brilliancies and many errors reported here, each player made thousands of sound, accurate decisions which go unheralded because the right play or bid is unspectacular.

**The Italians**

I was, I admit, very much surprised by my final tabulation on the Italian players:

I had always thought of Avarelli and Belladonna as the third-string Italian pair, and apparently the Italians agreed. In New York last year they played less than any of the others, and in Como they shared second billing with Chiaradia and D'Alelio. But they were clearly the best pair around this year.

My estimate is that fairly good play will lose one IMP every four boards. Par, then, is .250 (and it is not common to play well under the pressure of the World Championship match). So the record of Belladonna and Avarelli as a pair is truly remarkable.

There were very few charges against them. . . . Their system cost Belladonna and Avarelli a small loss on Deal 94 when they reached the wrong partial, but almost all of their infrequent bidding troubles seemed to arise after takeout doubles. . . . a fourth occurred on Deal 68:
On a singleton-club lead Avarelli had to go down two, for 500. At the other table Crawford was down one in three spades, so the U.S. gained 5 IMP.

Forquet opened a high club and shifted to his singleton diamond. Stone won in dummy and led the heart ten, which was allowed to hold. Now he played a club from dummy, and Siniscalco did not rise with his queen or duck—he played the club ten. When this held he gave Forquet a diamond ruff, was put back in by the marked underlead in clubs to his queen, and gave Forquet another ruff to set the contract. Nicely done.

Of course Stone had made the defense easier than was necessary. Instead of playing a club from dummy he should ruff a spade and play the heart king. To beat the contract now Forquet must lead the club jack to be overtaken by the queen, and after ruffing a diamond must underlead again on the mere chance of finding West with the club ten.

It was ungenerous of Stone not to give Forquet the opportunity for such brilliance.

North has heard the opening heart bid by East, and he knows that his run-out to two hearts shuts out possible contracts of two clubs or two diamonds; he could bid one notrump if he so chose. D'Alelio should pass two hearts doubled even with a void, and so his singleton ten is a bonanza.

The Swedes said afterwards that either West shouldn't open a non-opening bid or East shouldn't force to game. That's true, but many pairs would be in game at IMPs. Switch West's hearts and clubs and four spades is acceptable.

**Challenge the Champs**

conducted by Phillip Alder

Challenge the Champs is a continuing bidding battle. Each month, two leading pairs compete, the Incumbents (they bid last month too) and the Newcomers (who will be back next month) bidding deals from actual play (taken from old tournament reports or submitted by readers). Awards assigned to final contracts are estimates of the matchpoint expectancy on a 12 top in a strong pairs contest. Awards are rounded off to the nearest full matchpoint. An award embraces all lower equivalent contracts in the same strain.

The deals for next month's match are elsewhere in this issue.
**FALLENIUS-NILSLAND vs. LARS & MORTEN LUND MADSEN**

This month we have a Scandinavian battle. The Incumbents, trying for their fourth victory toward a place in the Challenge of the Decade, are Bjorn Fallenius and Mats Nilsland from Sweden. Well, Fallenius is Swedish by birth, but now he lives primarily in New York City. They use a strong-club system with five-card majors, 14-16 notrump and a nebulous one diamond. When holding at least game-going values, they usually ascend into a relay auction.

The Newcomers are brothers Lars and Morten Lund Madsen. Both are students at Copenhagen University, Lars studying economics and Morten mathematics. They were the mainstays of the Danish team that won last year's World Junior Championship, and have had several medal-winning performances in European junior events. However, Lars, at 25, is too old for further success at that level. Morten, at 23, has two more years of eligibility. The Danes use an Acol-style system but with five-card one-spade openings. They employ a variable notrump (11-14 nonvul., 15-17 vul.) and, most unusually for Europeans, weak two-bids in three suits.

Our thanks to these readers who sent deals used in this match: John Uchida, Seattle, Deal 2; Michael Whitman, San Francisco, Deal 3; Martin Miller, Rochester, NY, Deal 4; L. J. Nee, Auburn, WA, Deal 7; Mark Kinzer, IL, Deal 8; Bill Ahrens, Milpitas, CA, Deal 9; John Plaut, Santiago, Deal 10. Deals 5 and 6 are from the Becker Archive.

**General Conclusions**

After all I have written it may come as a surprise that I consider the Italy-United States match to have been played quite well. Technically, the match was on a very high plane indeed—there were few errors of dummy play or defense; of these few, not more than three or four were really glaring. And the bidding errors were generally ones involving fine judgment, not gross overbids or underbids.

Slam bidding was the worst department for both teams. The U.S. bid twelve slams—five made, seven went down. We missed four good slams that would have made, and one good one that wouldn't. One of the U.S. slams that made should have been beaten; conversely, one of those beaten should have been made. All in all, a miserable showing.

The Italians were no better. They bid only eight slams—four made, four didn't. That looks almost respectable, but they missed five good slams, and, of the four they bid and made, two were in the wrong contract and one should have been beaten. One of the slams they bid and went down on was a good contract, but they luckily stayed out of another good one that only failed because of stacked cards.

I came to no conclusions about the "battle of the systems." Somehow, there were very few strictly systemic swings—either pickups or losses—for the Neapolitan or Roman systems. Roth-Stone seemed to have quite a few systemic losses, but the results are inconclusive. The other Americans did fairly well with psychics, unimpressively with preempts, jump overcalls, disastrously with weak two-bids. I saw no signs that anyone was losing points through unfamiliarity with the meaning of his opponents' bidding. The swings were due to judgment, rarely to system at all.

Over the long match luck was fairly even. The Americans lost, on my reckoning, 51 IMP through unlucky swings. They gained 44 IMP in lucky ones. (By luck, I mean good contracts going down, bad ones making; slams on finesses, guess situations on lead, etc.) We were, then, slightly unlucky, but not enough to make the difference.

We lost because we were outplayed; we did a few more good things than the Italians did, but a lot more bad things. But don't believe that vague impression floating around (at least here in New York) that the U.S. players performed miserably in Como. That's not true. I think they played better than almost any

of our previous World Championship teams. According to my calculations our teams would have won in 1955, 1956 and 1957 if they had played as well as the U.S. team this year. It's just that the Italians put on a real championship performance and played better still.

**A Jacobean Proposal**

*by Henry Bethe, Ithaca, NY*

The Jacoby Two-Notrump strong major-suit raise responded to the need for an efficient forcing raise after limit raises came into vogue. Developments in bidding theory since that time suggest that the original method can profitably be modified.

Popular competitive-bidding theory holds that a side with a nine-card fit and half the deck should compete to the three level—so why not get there quickly? Accordingly, a current trend is the use of a direct double raise of a major with hands weaker than limit-raise strength. This, in turn has led to a search for alternative mechanisms for the limit raise. A common solution has been to devote the entire range from two of opener's major to three of opener's major to raises. Using so many bids for this purpose is not productive; my proposal, below, avoids this waste.

**A Revised Jacoby Two-Notrump**

A response of two notrump to one of a major promises a limit raise or better—that is, seven-and-a-half or fewer losers in the losing trick count or a hand with four potentially working important cards; the hand may include a singleton with exactly six losers, or as few as three trumps if responder has no singleton. Opener rebids as follows:

*Three clubs:* Six or more losers; a minimum. In effect, this says, "I may be passing a limit raise." [If responder rebids three diamonds, a strong relay, opener shows his distribution using the "higher-bid scheme" for bids of three hearts or higher, shown below. Alternatively, responder may bid three of opener's major to show a limit raise, bid the other major to show six losers and some singleton (opener can relay to discover the short suit), or make a higher new-suit bid to show concentrated values in a hand marginally worth a slam try.]

*Three diamonds:* Key-card Blackwood. [After the Blackwood asks are complete, the partnership can employ help-suit bids or asking bids.]

*Higher-bid scheme:* Any bid above three diamonds shows five or fewer

losers.

*Three of opener's major* shows no singleton, but not 5-3-3-2 (usually 5-4-2-2, or 6-3-2-2 with weak trumps). [Responder's cheapest rebid is a relay for side length. Opener shows his four-card suit, using three notrump to show spades when hearts are agreed, or bids four of the agreed suit to show 6-3-2-2 with weak trumps. Responder can relay again for loser count (which should be without adjustments so that responder can count his cover cards). If responder does not start with a relay, his bid shows a splinter in a six-loser hand.]

*Three notrump* shows 5-3-3-2. [Then, four clubs by responder asks for key cards; other bids show the six-loser splinter hand.]

*Three of the other major or four of a minor* shows shortness in the suit bid. [Responder can relay for loser count with the cheapest bid, otherwise cue-bid.]

*Four of opener's major* shows long, strong trumps with no singleton. [Responder can relay for loser count with the cheapest bid, otherwise cue-bid.]

In order to make this structure easy to learn and to remember, I have not made it maximally efficient. Where possible, bids mean what they sound like: three notrump shows notrump shape, a jump in trumps shows good trumps, rebidding the agreed major shows no shortness, and so forth.
**Book Reviews**

Newspaper columnists who write for local publications suffer under a severe handicap: They are constrained by the truth. How they must frequently yearn to change a card or two, or a call or play, to purify a deal of its real-world flaws. This hindrance reduces the flavor of some of the articles in **The Times Book of Bridge** (Batsford; 112 pages; $13.95 paperbound), an eclectic collection of Robert Sheehan's work for *The Times* of London. Despite this drawback and some unevenness in level of topic sophistication and depth of analysis, we think most avid bridge readers, especially non-Britons, will find the book worthwhile. Warts and all, the deals have points of interest. Sheehan, one of the current generation's most successful European competitors, has a good eye for what serious players will find intriguing. Several problem situations present fresh challenges. We singled out non-Britons above because the parts of the book we liked best were those that revolved around in-depth portraits of several of the leading British bridge personalities, both alive and dead. Some of the deals and anecdotes in those chapters were new to us, and the section on the late Irving Rose sparkled brightly enough to provide sufficient light for an entire book.

Available from The Bookshelf [TIMES]

On the surface, Alan Mould's **"Preempts"** (Batsford; 143 pages; $16.95 paperback) is designed to present the fundamental techniques of opening and responding to preemptives, to describe today's widely varying styles and the tradeoffs among them, to create awareness of the opportunities for obstructive tactics other than openings, and to add occasional observations and personal comments about which choices of approach and method seem to the author more or less likely to be successful.

This book does all that, but . . . surprise! The best part is a large, excellently presented, theoretical section on card values, how to judge whether your strength is offensive or defensive, comparison of risks and rewards—in short, just the sort of knowledge one needs to advance from formula follower to intelligent bidder. This discussion is simple, easy to follow, and right on target. It is introduced in the context of deciding whether or not to open a three-bid, and thus is mildly mislabeled (because it applies much more generally), but this part alone is worth the price of the book to an improving player. That's two winners for Mould's commonsense approach to advanced bidding topics; his book on slam bidding has similar positive characteristics.

Available from The Bookshelf [PRE]

*        *        *

The second book in the Card Play Made Easy series by Ron Klinger and Andrew Kambites is **"Know Your Suit Combinations"** (Gollancz; 96 pages; $13.95 paperbound). The book begins with and throughout emphasizes the critical concept in the area of analyzing how to handle individual suit holdings: distinguishing between the abstract correct play in isolation and the appropriate handling in the context of trying to make a contract. This theme is handled well, especially in the 36 quiz deals that augment the lessons and numerous individual suit discussions. The tutorial level is elementary to low intermediate, but most of the quiz deals stretch to greater challenges. Overall, the book is good, but we cannot give it our highest recommendation because the authors goof in a few places, messing up an occasional analysis while trying to set up the desired theme. We sympathize; we've been there ourselves.

Available from The Bookshelf [CPME2]

*        *        *

Tony Sowter's **"Step-By-Step Competitive Bidding"** (Batsford; 143 pages; $16.95 paperbound) is a solid introduction to contested auctions, both what we would call "competitive" (your side opens, the opponents act) and "defensive" (the opponents open). Unfortunately, as we have seen before in similar British books, the overcalling style on opposite sides of the Atlantic is so different that the text will be misleading to American readers. To the "what happened and why" type of tournament report, Edgar brought fearless journalism. Prior to his entry into this realm, even the pungent criticisms of a Moyse were not directed at players. Bidding philosophies, systems, approaches and myths were blamed for failures during the auction; partnership defense was treated similarly when possible. Other writers were even more restrained. For the less disguisable individual errors in play and defense, authors (even Moyse) sometimes retreated behind not naming the player involved.

Every now and then, someone dared to say who had committed a howler during the play. On these occasions, the blow was usually softened by a not-so-gentle reminder that the perpetrator was well known as the best player in 40 counties in three different states, and had enjoyed that status ever since a tot. True, Player X might have fluffed once before, many years ago, during a back-room game for score caddies . . . Board 20; West dealer; Both vulnerable

The last board concluded a remarkable 50-imp spurt over five boards. On the Vu-Graph, we noticed that Rosenberg intentionally delayed placing his pass card on the tray after Chemla had bid five clubs. This "screen huddling" is entirely ethical and proper. The screen is supposed to conceal fast calls as well as huddles; if a player makes a fast call, his opponent may delay the movement of the tray so that the speed of the call is not known on the other side of the screen. Whether this had any effect on Perron's losing decision to bid the slam we will never know, but the result was a fine one for the U. S. In the Closed Room, West doubled five clubs. The substantial pickup completed a dramatic turnaround and gave the U. S. the match by 23 imps.

**Edgar Kaplan Remembered, II**

by Jeff Rubens

**The Tournament Scene**

While the behavioral pot simmered through the late '50s and early '60s, in other dimensions tournaments kept cooking in more or less the usual way. To be sure, "usual" then was a bit different from "usual" now. For example, in the age before fixed partnerships became the norm in serious events, there was some respect for individual contests. Indeed, the Masters Individual was regarded as a premier event. And the contest for winning the most master points in a year (then called the McKenney, now named after Barry Crane) was regarded as significant, both by the general public and by the

tournament crowd. Nowadays, each of these areas enjoys only a small fraction of its former status.

Among the top players, Edgar Kaplan was one of the least capable in individual events. (By far the most successful stars in this universe were the ones with the most placid personalities, such as B. Jay Becker and Norman Kay.) However, in 1957, when Edgar won the McKenney trophy with what was then considered an astronomical masterpoint total (chicken feed in today's inflation-wracked economy), he somehow won the Masters Individual—oops, I mean the Life Masters Individual; even then, events had to be reclassified to reduce the number of in-

four hearts. . . . A grand is possible after a follow-up exchange of cue-bids."

**Carl Hudecek**: "c. Six diamonds. The direct route to slam. If I had chosen a three-spade advance, and partner then bid three notrump, I would pass."

If we had to make one bid for our lives, we would choose six diamonds. But why should we give up on seven, easy to reach opposite many fitting minimums? As to passing three notrump, anything we'd print would be censored by the editor, so we had best say nothing at all.

**Arthur Robinson**: "c. Four clubs. I assume this is 100% forcing."

Yes, we assume that. Too bad it has nothing to do with your hand. Is this some new system where new suits in competition show voids?

Let's get back to reality and see if we should start with three hearts or three spades. The three-spade bidders are trying to paint a complete picture.

**Jeff Rubens**: "b. Three spades, then four hearts. Three hearts first is unlikely to accomplish much. If I can get away with three spades, my later cue-bids will support diamonds and show, roughly, my hand pattern."

**Kit Woolsey**: "b. Three spades, then four hearts, then five diamonds (probably). As I can't show my club void conveniently, this sequence gives the best picture of my hand."

They're not bidding three spades to try to get to spades, but simply to show their shape. Sure, and they'll get that chance if partner bids three notrump. The problem is that partner might end-

play them into a guess by raising to four spades. We'd rather make sure North knows we're showing a monster hand for diamonds while there's still room to investigate.

**John Lowenthal**: "b. Three spades, then five clubs. As in problem A, source of tricks first, then splinters, cue-bids, etc. I plan to drive to slam."

Not bad, but you're lucky you had room to splinter. If partner were unkind enough to rebid four clubs (not really a surprise), then where would you be? You'd have a really hard time convincing him that you have enormous diamond support.

Given South's heart holding, it should be a bit of a surprise that North bids three notrump. Without knowing partner's rebid, it seems that we should make sure we do everything we can to announce our diamonds.

**Chip Martel**: "a. Three hearts, then four hearts. Should show the ace (with a singleton, I'd probably bid four hearts directly). Slam prospects are too good to bid anything but a slam try in diamonds."

Chip then went on to discuss the merits of four spades as a fit bid, but he didn't like the fact that it took up so much room. We'd rather not make a fit bid with a side void and a side ace. Something like,

showing how a declarer could plan an effective pseudo-squeeze scientifically. There were two main themes, leaving entryless winners as a pseudo-threat in dummy, and the principle exemplified by this deal:

If it were a social game, or a charity game, by all means, let the opponents pick up and do whatever they want. But, in a serious bridge tournament, a lead out of turn is just like any other mistake. Our opponent carelessly forgets to draw the last trump. He plays a side winner. Instead of ruffing it with our tiny trump, should we say, "f. None

of the above. You may take back your play and draw my last trump"? No, of course not. Bridge is a game where you must be focused; not knowing whose lead it is should cause a loss, just as any other lapse in concentration. That's why we have rules. **TEST YOUR PLAY SOLUTIONS**

(Problems on page 9.)

**Solution A**

Suppose you play trumps early, taking two rounds after winning the opening lead. If spades turn out to be four-one, you are in trouble. If you switch to hearts, the defender with four trumps may be able to ruff in and lead a trump, leaving you a trick short. Alternatively, if you take two club ruffs after the second trump you will still face a dilemma: when you lead a fourth round of trumps, the long-trump defender may have another club; should you instead try hearts, the third round may be ruffed, cutting you off from the pitch for your diamond loser.

**Editorial**

**Ring in the New**

Along with 1998, we welcome to *The Bridge World* staff Associate Editor Phillip Alder. An Englishman by birth who now lives in Florida, he brings outstanding credentials to his new position: one of the world's leading syndicated columnists, author or co-author of successful books in several areas of bridge, and a former editor of *Bridge Magazine*. Some of his articles have appeared in our pages.

Phillip's main area of responsibility will be *Challenge the Champs*, where he recently appeared as a contestant. Subscribers have had to read (suffer?) the views of Kaplan and Rubens in this column for thirty years; it's high time they were given the opportunity to endure a different set of biases. The beginning of Alder's tenure also marks a change in the editorial policy governing the department: To increase the relevance of the descriptions for most readers, the text for each deal will include a possible approach to the auction using Bridge World Standard. In most cases, a third ("standard") auction, or beginning of an auction, will be presented. This adjustment will hold sway during a trial period, while readers' comments are evaluated.

The new year will also usher in minor changes in the *Master Solvers' Club*, where we are dropping several not-too-popular statistics: the "Solvers' Percentage," for which it is too difficult to obtain anything near a random sample while maintaining the magazine's production schedule; the "Experts' Honor Roll," the purpose of which continues to be misinterpreted despite repeated in-print explanations; and, correspondingly, the Experts' and Solvers' averages.

This issue marks the first absence of *Rate Your Own Game* in over 25 years. The editor has nostalgic feelings about this column, but only a handful of readers bewailed its pending departure, proposed in September. To avoid closing the door too firmly, we will if possible include an occasional article of this type in response to suggestions to present an idea or area of bidding not already covered by the department.

To make way for other series, the *Swiss Match* scheduled for this issue has been postponed. Our current expectation is that it will appear in the April issue.

* * *

**New Location; New Facilities**

*The Bridge World* has relocated to the suburbs, moving out of Manhattan for the first time in its almost-seventy-year history. Our new address is 717 White Plains Road, Suite 106, Scarsdale, NY 10583-5009.
